Award.AwardTitle: SaTC: Student Travel Support for IEEE CNS 2016

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This grant supports 8-12 graduate students for their travel to attend the 2016 IEEE Conference on Communications and Network Security (CNS). The CNS workshop is a relatively young conference started by the IEEE Communications Society in 2013, focused on the lower levels of the networking stack (i.e., at the physical layer), as compared to the higher levels addressed by conferences such as the Network and Distributed System Security Symposium (NDSS), ACM Conference on Computer and Communications Security (CCS), etc. By supporting attendance for these graduate students, this award helps grow a next generation of researchers with expertise in secure communications. Participation of women and underrepresented minorities will be encouraged.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Buffalo
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2016 IEEE IEEE Conference on Communications and Network Security was held in Philadelphia, PA USA from October 17 to October 19 of 2016. This is a conference series in IEEE Communications Society (ComSoc) core conference portfolio and the only ComSoc conference focusing solely on cyber security. The conference is a spin-off of the IEEE INFOCOM, the premier ComSoc conference on networking. The goal of this conference series is to make a preeminent technical venue for presenting new research results in all practical and theoretical aspects of communications and network security.

The conference this year consisted of a program 38 papers in the main conference program and is supplemented by five (5) workshops. The conference also had two keynote talks by leading researchers, Dr. Don Towsley, a Professor at University of Massachusetts Amherst, and Dr. Cliff Wang, a Division Chief of Computing Sciences at the US Army Research Office. Finally, the conference had two panels on software defined networks security and wireless networks security, moderated by Anita Nikolich (National Science Foundation) and Wenjing Lou (National Science Foundation & Virginia Tech).  162 researchers attended the main conference, 98 people attended the workshops, and the total attendance was 217 (with 43 people attending both). Given that we had 38 papers accepted in the main conference program, the attendee/paper ratio is 4.3, a very good indicator of the success of the conference.

This project provided funding support to 19 graduate students in the United States to attend this premiere conference. The travel awards have targeted graduate students, in particular, women and underrepresented minority students, since attending conferences is an important part of their educational experience, and they often have limited travel funds. Paper authors have also been given priority in consideration. The awards were decided by the award selection committee consisting of four professors including two females. Participants had the opportunity to present their work, attend panel and keynote sessions, and interact with other students and leading experts in the field.


Last Modified: 04/20/2017
Modified by: Aziz Mohaisen
